Sharpedo

Toxapex

Pangoro

Kingambit

G-Slowking
>Malamar’s old friend, but they have since parted ways: Malamar fears him but won’t reveal why. Has no henchmen, no army.
There’s a lot more, but that’s a taste for now

com:
"i am tired" edition

Old bread: >>52529483

Welcome to the Raidcat / 6 Star Tera Raid Meta Thread

>lol I can solo 5 star raids I don't need your ugly cat
6 stars are infinitely harder than 5 and extremely annoying. You can do them the normal way and risk wasting your time, or accept the raidcat as your raid savior.

>What's the meta?
4 Perrserkers. Their Hidden Ability stacks multiplicatively and, if you follow the flowchart, you can one-shot most raids.

>What's the raidcat like?
Perrserker @ Lum Berry
Level 100
Ability: Steely Spirit (Hidden Ability)
EVs: 252 Atk / 252 Speed (Host) or HP (Joiner)
Adamant Nature
- Iron Head
- Screech
- Swords Dance
- Taunt (Host) / Helping Hand (Joiner)

>Host? Joiner? Flowchart?
There's a small difference in strategy whether you are hosting or joining a raid and a specific flowchart. See OP pic.

>Does this work every time?
No, but it's one of the only consistent strategies that you can follow. It's not great against Pokemon that have strong and/or STAB Fire/Fighting/Ground moves, and if their Tera resists Steel it can also take a few more turn (but still doable).

>So what's the hype?
Catraids are simple to organize, have plenty of flowcharts, and finish the job very quickly. It's about efficiency.

>I have a question about raids...
Check OP pic.

>How to get cat with HA?
Language Teacher sidequest, then use an Ability Patch to change its ability. Patch is an 11% drop from 6 Star Raids.

>I tried breeding but I'm getting Kantonian Meowth
Make the G-Meowth hold an Everstone

>wtf I did that but none of them have Steely Spirit
G-Meowth's HA is Unnerve, it becomes Steely Spirit upon evolution.

For other viable meta strategies and mons, Ctrl+F OTHERMONS

For specific strategies, Ctrl+F HARDRAIDS

Use this thread to trade for raidcats, to organize (raidcat) raids, or just to discuss and ask questions about raids in general.

>in 1981, Satoshi Tajiri, a dude who loved video games, created a fanzine called Game Freak
>The magazine was of middling popularity, but made the company successful
>Then in 1990, Tajiri came up with an idea of capsule monsters, ie capmon, which would work perfectly with the game boy and their link cables
>during the early 90s, his company would make a few games, none of whom were released outside of japan (except Yoshi), and in 1995, he pitched the idea of his capmon to nintendo

sub: Throh should be a model for all Fighting-Types
com: I know what you're thinking, Throh? That ugly, clothes wearing, dex filler who's never been good competitively? What could Throh possibly have that other Fighting-Types should copy? Well, to demonstrate my point, think of any two or three Fighting-Types that aren't Throh, look them up, take a look at recommended movesets and you might see a few things. Usually they'll have close combat, some rock type coverage (most likely stone edge) and maybe knock off for utility, there's not a lot of variety in how fighting types fight, despite representing dozens of differing fighting styles. Then there's Throh, who doesn't even learn close combat and instead relies on moves likes storm throw, circle throw, etc. because it's based on a judoka, most other Fighting-Types just don't represent their fighting style as well as Throh and end up as a brain-dead offense type of fighter that just throws out close combats. Power creep and balance is a big issue with Pokémon games but I feel like Fighting-Types have suffered in a different way as their identities are overshadowed by optimal choices. In an ideal, more balanced game, I think all Fighting-Types should be a little more like Throh.

>>52534530
There's fundamentally no way to make Pokemon hard, just tedious or frustrating. If you set a level cap and give trainers compfag teams and AI that will invalidate a ton of mons which is unacceptable since the core appeal of Pokemon is choosing mons you like. Plus there's the aspect of randomness in fights so the most efficient option can be to bruteforce and get the luck you need. Getting fucked by RNG is also not hard, just frustrating. You'd need to rework the entire battle system and all Pokemon stats and movepools to make the game hard while keeping the core appeal of using mons you like while also giving rare candies to minimize tedious grinding in which case it still becomes more or less a glorified puzzle game in the end.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>52535155
>Realistically I would just make it so gym's get 6 pokemon sooner by around gym 4.

Gym battles are formal Pokémon League events, so they have extra rules.
>The challenger can only use three Pokémon.
>The challenger can't use items, but the Gym Leader can.
>The gym interior has weather, terrain. etc. which gives home field advantage.
>Sleep/Freeze/evasion/etc. clauses are in effect
Elite Four + Champion don't have the first two restrictions.

Villain teams also have special rules, but more in the "cheating" sense.
>2-on-1 battles
>Ambushes where the opponent gets a free turn at the start of battle
>Enemy trainer can attack your Pokémon by setting hazards, putting it to sleep, etc.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>52540687
I think the main problem with that is that it relies on the AI knowing what to do with the information it's been given. As it stands even the AI just having a chance to switch to a resist if they see your mon's stab is supereffective would be an improvement.
Otherwise the answer would probably be to give gym teams more moves like U-Turn or Parting Shot that would give them a chance of mixing things up without wasting a turn switching.

>>52540822
In the context of making a separate hard mode, I don't think it's unreasonable to expect that it can't be swept through with any random team. That probably doesn't need to be top-tier competitive sets with level caps and super-AI, but if people are picking hard mode for a challenge, needing to swap out your team members to deal with something is part of that. The normal difficulty mode can and should exist alongside that just fine, and would allow for the exact experience you're talking about.

Kofu is like the only one that's oddly extravagant. What with that silly ocean wave hair and facial hair. Coupled with the apron that's a bit more theatrical than you'd ever wear normally. The only excuse for it would be Kofu putting on a show as the gym leader, which is admittedly the actual reason for it. but still.


Iono is admittedly way out there, but she also just looks just like a vtuber (even though she is a flesh streamer). So compared to her real life contemporaries she is nothing out of the ordinary at all, and she comfortably stands out in her role as a streamer. No other character stands out like she does, and yet the way she does is perfectly in tune with her streaming gig.

Brassius isn't even that weird. He is just an artfag. The whip is a bit much and that jacket is some real hipster shit. But that's about it.

And that's it. Katy is just looks like a plain pastry chef. That slight web emblem on the apron is like the only thing that stands out.
Ryme looks extremely plain and reserved for a rapper celebrity.
Tulip is is just a model.
And maybe the colours are slightly unusual for Grusha, but the clothes are just outside winter gear.
And Larry is straight up an office wagie stereotype. The most grounded of them all. Straight up his thing.

Strictly speaking the only one who is out there is Iono, but she has a good reason for it in-game that isn't over played.
Kofu meanwhile is only a little over the top, though has less of a reason to be.
And that's it. Though it's not like being over the top is some inexcusable crime or anything, but compared to most of the past designs, gif related, these new trainers are absolutely more grounded.

The last two options just seem like too big of a shake up. The way Pokémon works is pretty much enshrined into our culture now it would be radically disruptive to the franchise to change it now. I think the middle option could work only if it is something else like abilities and that's all they're changing. Messing without damage is calculated and having different levels of weakness adds too much complexity when it's meant to be simple rock paper scissors type shit. But doing something like giving Pokemon two separate ability slots or creating a new characteristic that can affect how a Pokemon plays -- like having each egg group give its Pokémon some built in special trait, making the old contest stats have an impact on battles, or having Pokémon use a pool of PP for all their attacks -- that would literally be game changing
